I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic  approach  for  the  Competitiveness,  Industrial  Modernization,  and  Trade 
Acceleration Program, and (ii) a proposed policy-based loan (PBL) to the Republic of Indonesia 
for subprogram 1 of the Competitiveness, Industrial Modernization, and Trade Acceleration 
Program. 
 
2.  The proposed programmatic approach aims to foster a more competitive and investment-
friendly business environment in Indonesia and to support an accelerated economic recovery 
from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. It combines PBLs with technical assistance 
(TA)  and  knowledge  work  to  support  government  reforms.  A  programmatic  approach  was 
selected as it enables keeping the focus on the overall aim of the program while providing the 
flexibility to address the complexity of multiyear reforms spanning various government ministries 
and the uncertainty arising from the pandemic. 
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  Macroeconomic context and impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of the 
unprecedented  impacts  of  the  COVID-19  pandemic,  the  economy  contracted  in  2020—by 
2.1%—for the first time since the Asian financial crisis.1 The poverty rate increased to 10.2% in 
 
2020 from 9.2% in 2019, reversing the gains of prior years, while the unemployment rate rose to 
7.1% in 2020 from 5.3% in 2019. Per capita gross national income declined to $3,870 in 2020, 
and Indonesia was reclassified as a lower middle-income country in 2021.2 The Ministry of 
Finance expects growth in 2021 of 3.7%–4.5%, down from its earlier outlook of 5.0%–5.3% due 
   
to the knock-on effects arising from the mobility restrictions put in place to stem the spike in 
COVID-19  infections. 3  The  government’s  macroeconomic  framework,  which  guides  the 
medium-term fiscal strategy, remains satisfactory. Given the comprehensive social protection and 
stimulus packages to address the pandemic, the 2021 budget targets a deficit of 5.7% of gross 
domestic product (GDP), while it aims to return to pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels of fiscal 
prudence by 2023.4 With inflation remaining subdued, the central bank has kept the policy rate at 
3.5%, its lowest level since 2016. General government debt increased to 37.0% of GDP in 2020 
from 30.6% in 2019,5 while total external debt increased to 39.4% of GDP in 2020 from 36.1% in 
2019.6 Nonperforming loan ratios have risen slightly, while the banking sector’s capital adequacy 
ratio remains comfortably above the regulatory minimum.7 However, external and public debts

4.  Indonesia aspires to become a high-income country. The government has set a target 
of becoming a high-income country and transforming its economy to be the fifth largest in the 
world by 2045.9 The abundant natural resource endowment, demographic dividend, and a large 
domestic market provide the foundation to attain this goal. However, Indonesia’s current growth 
momentum will not be sufficient. Indonesia’s economic growth peaked at 9.5% in 1995–1996, 
after which growth has declined. Following the Asian financial crisis in 1998 and until 2019, 
Indonesia’s economy grew at an average annual rate of 5.0%, which is not sufficient to support 
its long-term aspiration. For Indonesia to achieve high-income country status by 2045 and support 
an accelerated economic recovery from the pandemic, a growth rate of about 7% per annum will 
be necessary. 
 
5.  Sources of growth remain narrow. Because the economic expansion has been largely 
driven by the export of primary commodities, sources of economic growth have been narrowing 
and becoming more volatile. This is exposing the economy to deteriorating terms of trade and, in 
turn, placing balance-of-payment constraints on growth. Manufacturing value added as a share 
of GDP declined from 32% in 2002 to 20% in 2019, while employment in manufacturing as a 
share of total employment was estimated to be 14.7% in 2018.10 Women’s share of employment 
in manufacturing remained flat at 5.6% during 2001–2015, with a persistent gender wage gap.11 
In fact, labor productivity growth has been relatively low at 3.1% (1980–2019) compared with 
4.8% in Viet Nam.12 Moreover, only a few manufacturing firms in Indonesia grow to a size 
sufficient to drive productivity gains, including labor productivity, and innovation. Without structural 
reform, a faster growth rate will be difficult as Indonesia’s potential growth rate, when all resources 
are fully employed, has declined from 9.50% in 1995–1996 to 5.34% in 2017.13  
 
6.  Higher investments are imperative for faster and broader growth. Currently, private 
investment is concentrated in the resources sector and digital economy, with limited impact on 
job creation. Indonesia’s incremental capital output ratio (a measure of investment efficiency) rose 
to 6.3 in 2019 from 4.3 in 2006, compared with 3.4 in Viet Nam in 2019, indicating that the 
economy  requires  relatively  more  investment  to  support  growth  (Figure  1).  Indonesia  is 
considered a nascent country in terms of readiness to benefit from the fourth industrial revolution 
and emerging technologies. It ranked 85th (out of 131 economies) in the 2020 Global Innovation 
Index (behind Malaysia [33], Viet Nam [42], and Thailand [44]).14 Foreign direct investment (FDI) 
can play an instrumental role in bringing the latest technologies and know-how into Indonesia, 
while also strengthening its readiness for the future of production. However, between 2009 to 
2019, net FDI to Indonesia averaged only 1.9% of GDP, compared with 2.3% of GDP in countries

7.  The business environment is not conducive to investment. A host of issues afflicts 
the investment environment and private sector development in general. An outdated approach to 
business licensing coupled with difficulties in setting up operations discourage FDI in job-creating 
sectors such as manufacturing. Despite reducing the time required to start a business, it still takes 
13 days to complete 11 steps for starting a business. The business licensing process can be 
confusing and cumbersome for the investors, with differences in processes between central and

subnational levels and among subnational administrations. While FDI often plays an important 
role in technology transfer and spurring domestic investments, Indonesia has the highest barriers 
to FDI among the Group of Twenty (G20) countries (Figure 2). Its score in the OECD index on 
restrictiveness to FDI worsened to 0.34 in 2019 (with 0 = openness) from 0.31 in 2010, as 
compared to the global average of 0.06.16 There are many practical impediments facing foreign 
investors; for example, poor governance of land transactions makes it difficult to secure sites for 
factories. Indonesia has established special economic zones (SEZs) in selected geographical 
locations to address the many operational obstacles faced by investors. However, the uptake by 
the private sector has been limited because of the overlapping jurisdictions of the central and local 
governments and a lack of clarity on the benefits of being in an SEZ.  
 
8.  Barriers inhibit trade. Well-functioning trade and transport logistics are the backbone of 
any growing economy. Indonesia’s logistics systems are fragmented and inefficient, resulting in 
high costs for the private sector. Indonesia ranked 46th in the World Bank’s Logistics Performance 
Index in 2018, behind Malaysia (41), Thailand (32), and Viet Nam (39). The time and costs for 
documentary compliance as well as cross border trade can be substantial for the private sector. 
The prevalence of trade barriers contributed to the country’s weak integration in global value chain 
(GVC). Indonesia’s participation in GVCs through both forward and backward linkages declined 
from 2000 to 2017. Forward GVC participation declined from 21.5% in 2000 to 12.9% in 2017, 
while backward participation declined from 16.9% to 10.1% during the same period.17 For its 
exports to remain competitive, Indonesia will also need to improve the quality of its market access 
in key export destinations. In general, Indonesia needs to open up its economy more if it wants to 
sustain quality growth. 
 
9.  Small firms find it difficult to grow and to upgrade their operations. Micro, small and 
medium-sized enterprises accounted for 99.9% of the total number of firms and employed 97% 
of the total workforce, while the majority of businesses owned by women operated in the informal 
sector (footnote 1). Because of low levels of productivity, firms in Indonesia are unable to grow, 
function as competitive suppliers of inputs to FDI, or meaningfully participate in global value 
chains. Firm productivity is low because investments in upgrading technology and the skill sets of 
workers are limited. Of the total expenditure on research and development (R&D) (0.08% of 
GDP), only 26% is carried out by the private sector in Indonesia, compared to 73% in Thailand.18 
Firms point to financial constraints as barriers to the adoption of technologies. Moreover, less 
than 9% of formal employees in Indonesia have participated in certified workplace training, and 
less than 8% of firms offer formal training to employees. High barriers to entry shields incumbent 
firms and allows them to survive despite low productivity, while opportunities to partner with larger 
enterprises, including FDI, are limited. In addition, there are severe local content restrictions in 
infrastructure and other investments, which place Indonesia at a comparative disadvantage when 
it comes to quality investments.

B.  Policy Reform, ADB’s Value Addition, and Sustainability 
 
11.  Government’s  landmark  reforms.  To  address  these  constraints  on  growth,  the 
government recently launched critical and wide-ranging structural reforms. These reforms are 
guided by the policy direction laid out by President Joko Widodo for his second term in office and 
include  promoting  investments,  simplifying  bureaucracy,  and  accelerating  human  capital 
development.23 In  October  2020,  Indonesia’s  Parliament  approved  the  Job  Creation  Law 
(commonly referred to as the Omnibus Law) that amended 78 laws and targeted improvements 
to  business  licensing  procedures;  hiring  of  workers;  economic  zones;  micro,  small,  and 
medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs); and research, innovation, and ease of doing business. 
Subsequently,  the  government  has  issued  accompanying  regulations,  demonstrating  its 
commitment to the implementation of the reforms. In addition, the government’s reform agenda 
also targets improvements to logistics and trade as well as increasing firm productivity. It also 
adopted the first national definition of MSMEs owned by women, which will help with the formal 
registration of businesses owned by women and support their growth.24  
 
12.  Programmatic  approach  and  budget  support.  The  program,  consisting  of  three 
subprograms, is designed to be an integral part of the government’s post-COVID-19 pandemic 
recovery strategy. It will focus on creating an enabling environment for investments, easing 
barriers to trade, and growing and upscaling enterprises. Under the programmatic approach, the 
subprograms are interlinked and seek to deepen and widen the reforms towards achieving the 
results targeted by the program (Box 1–3). The policy actions under subprogram 1 provide the 
first steps of reform with effective implementation under subprogram 2, followed by evaluation of 
the policy actions for improvement under subprogram 3. The program will complement ADB’s 
broader programmatic support to Indonesia in the areas of financial inclusion, human capital 
development, state-owned enterprise reform, and domestic resource mobilization under ADB’s 
country partnership strategy for Indonesia, 2020–2024.

1.  Reform Area 1: Creating an Enabling Environment for Investments 
 
13.  Making  businesses  easier  and  faster  to  start.  Policy  actions  in  this  cluster  will 
streamline the process for starting a business across national and subnational administrations. 
Under  subprogram  1,  the  government  newly  established  the  Ministry  of  Investment  and 
centralized business licensing powers that were previously spread across several agencies.25 
The government also installed the Online Single Submission Risk-Based Approach (OSS-RBA) 
system at the Ministry of Investment, which represents a risk-based approach to issuing business 
licenses following international good practice. This streamlined the previous system under which 
investors were required to separately obtain various types of licenses and/or permits before 
completing their investment plan and starting a business, which added costs and uncertainty. 
With the reforms under subprogram 1, the steps required for starting a business are halved and 
can be completed in 4 days from the previous 13 days. Empirical evidence shows that the removal 
of obstacles to obtaining business licenses is associated with an increase in investment flows and 
higher  productivity.  Under  subprogram  2,  the  government  will  upgrade  the  OSS-RBA  to 
incorporate regulations from all line ministries and local governments and roll out the licensing 
system across subnational administrations. At present, the online system for the issuance of 
business permits at the subnational level is not consistent across subnational jurisdictions. Under 
subprogram  3,  the  government  will  evaluate  the  reformed  business  licensing  system  and 
implement recommendations, with the aim of elevating Indonesia’s position as a top global 
destination for investment.

15.  Simplifying land-related transactions for investors. Policy actions in this cluster are 
dedicated to making it easier for investors to acquire land. Under subprogram 1, the government 
digitalized  land  management  systems,  which  will  allow  for  electronic  processing  of  land 
registration. It also increased the duration of certain land titles and the duration of their extensions: 
For example, the duration of rights-to-use land titles was automatically extended from 25 years to 
30 years, with a provision for extension for an additional 20 years. Improvements in property rights 
in Indonesia are associated with a 35% overall increase in productivity.28 Under subprogram 2, 
the government will simplify procedures for foreign ownership of strata titles (e.g., apartment units) 
and establish land titles for both above and below ground. Specifically, land titles for below ground 
will be established for the first time, which will be vital for infrastructure projects such as 
underground mass transit systems. Under subprogram 3, the government will strengthen the 
transparency and accuracy of information regarding landholder rights and protections.

in this cluster will make it easier to establish manufacturing and other facilities in SEZs. Under 
subprogram 1, the government centralized the management of SEZs under a national council, 
which eliminated the overlap of jurisdictions between the central and subnational governments 
and the associated complexity for businesses. It permitted, for the first time, the education and

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
33.  Poverty. The COVID-19 pandemic caused the poverty rate to spike, which stood at 10.1% 
in 2021—turning back years of progress in poverty reduction.37 The job losses, work stoppages, 
and reduced working hours may push many more workers and their families into poverty. In 2021, 
the unemployment rate stood at 6.3%, a slight improvement from 7.1% in 2020 that marked the 
highest rate in a decade and corresponded to about 9.8 million unemployed workers. Reform 
actions supported by the program will contribute to increased investments, job creation and 
poverty reduction. As starting businesses becomes easier and faster, it will encourage would-be 
entrepreneurs to start their own businesses, which in turn will create productive employment 
opportunities particularly for the youth. The program will also support the upscaling and growth of 
MSMEs, which are expected to have large impact on employment and poverty reduction.   
 
34.  Gender.  Subprogram  1  is  categorized  as  having  some  gender  elements,  while 
subprograms  2  and  3  will  target  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  female  labor  force 
participation rate (53.13%) is significantly lower than for males (82.41%). Accurate, regular, 
sex-disaggregated statistics are not yet available, because until 2020 there was no definition of 
businesses owned or led by women. Comprehensive, current, and disaggregated data are critical 
to designing and implementing a cohesive and well-coordinated approach to support MSMEs, 
including  those  owned  by  women.  Subprogram  1  focused  on  addressing  the  lack  of 
comprehensive data on businesses owned by women by integrating sex-disaggregated data in 
the system at the Ministry of Cooperatives and Small and Medium Enterprises. Subsequent 
subprograms will build on these actions by incorporating the definition of businesses owned by 
women as stated in the National Women’s Financial Inclusion Strategy (footnote 24) in the new 
integrated national plan on MSMEs. They will also support opening more opportunities for 
businesses to access markets through gender-responsive procurement, capacity building, and 
incubation programs for businesses owned by women. 
 
35.  Governance.  The  overall  investment  climate  in  Indonesia  is  dampened  by  the 
overabundance of regulations, procedures, and overlapping jurisdictions. For example, getting a 
business license or setting up operations in SEZs requires getting approval from a number of 
different authorities across the national and subnational governments. The long and ineffective 
business settlement process makes contract enforcements difficult.38 Moving goods into and 
within the country also requires approvals by various agencies spread across the government. 
The program supports the government’s reform efforts—that target whole-of-government—in 
streamlining governance issues that are holding back investments. The reforms are expected to 
increase predictability and transparency for the private sector in doing business in Indonesia.

established and is supported by systems that cover internal controls, accounting and reporting 
procedures, and internal and external audit systems.39 The 2017 public expenditure and financial

for fiscal management and control of budget execution, with 17 out of 31 indicators scoring above 
the basic alignment with international good practice.40 Indicators with particularly good results 
included transparency of public finance, accounting, and reporting. When compared to the 2011

on granting corporate income tax reduction facility (tax holiday) (issued on 24 September 2020); (iii) No. 16/PMK.010/2020 on net income reduction for new

on e-land certificate (issued on 12 January 2021). Clarity on land titles was established through Government Regulation No. 18 of 2021 on management rights, 
land titles, strata titles, and land registration (issued on 2 February 2021).  
e  Government Regulation No. 40 of 2021 on SEZs (issued on 2 February 2021) centralized the management of SEZs at the SEZ National Council, simplified 
obtaining land rights, and permitted new sectors to operate in the SEZs. The eight new business activities were in research and digital economy, education, health, 
sports, financial services, creative industry, SEZ management, and SEZ infrastructure development. 
f  The new National Logistic Ecosystem Masterplan, 2020–2024, including improvements to the physical layout of the ports, was officially launched and made

licensing submission, and interisland trade were established through Presidential Instruction No. 5 of 2020 (issued on 16 June 2020), Minister of Trade Regulation

interisland trade (issued on 12 November 2020).

through Minister of Trade Regulation No. 71 of 2020 on rules of origin and rules of origin document issuance for the goods from Indonesia under the ASEAN Trade 
in Goods Agreement (issued on 10 September 2020). The “reputable traders” mechanism was introduced through the Minister of Trade Regulation No. 17 of 2021 
on reputable exporters and importers (issues on 1 April 2021). The Indonesia–Australia Free Trade Agreement was ratified through Law No. 1 of 2020 on the 
Indonesia Australia Comprehensive Economic Partnership (enacted on 28 February 2020). The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership–a mega free 
trade agreement among the Asia-Pacific nations of Australia, Brunei, Cambodia, People’s Republic of China, Indonesia, Japan, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 
Malaysia, Myanmar, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Republic of Korea, Thailand, and Viet Nam–was signed to open markets for value-added exports 
as announced by the Joint Leaders Statement on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership.
